repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of -
            Health Sector Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector Management
            Project for Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            close coordination of policy lending and investment lending
            can greatly facilitate achievement of reforms. Although the
            policy lending included reforms across several sectors,
            there was a sustained sector focus on health that was
            central to achieving important synergies with the investment
            operations. Political obstacles can be overcome with
            effective planning and consultation, but will be
            insurmountable otherwise. The project manager should be
            chosen by agreement between the Bank and the Ministry of
            Health (MOH) as a bridge person, someone with political
            access but who is not reporting and subject to the MOH on a
            daily basis. Information technology (IT) components of
            health sector reform frequently encounter delays, whose risk
            can be mitigated through careful planning and flexibility.
            Qualified regional experts can be extremely effective as
            consultants and trainers. These consultants also contributed
            important demonstration effects of successful reform in
            other parts of the region.

18402028.trustfund:
TF026814-PHRD-FYR MACEDONIA: HEALTH
            SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector Management
            Project for Macedonia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: reform does not only concern
            technical health-related changes, but relies heavily on the
            political process. Government ownership and commitment were
            critical in the passage/amendments of key laws such as the
            Public Health Law and the Health Care Law and the adoption
            of the health sector strategy and the privatization
            strategy. Health sector reforms are complex and often take
            5-10 years. The Bank should adopt a longer-term approach in
            its support. Unfortunately this was not the case in the
            country as the first health Bank-supported project did not
            focus much on reforms and with the closing of this Loan the
            momentum gained will be lost. While supporting the Ministry
            of Health (MOH) in its role of priority setting and policy
            making, Bank teams promoted strong coordination between MOH
            and Health Insurance Fund (HIF). With membership from both
            institutions and joint training in various areas of the
            reform, World Banks (WGs) helped the two institutions better
            understand their roles. Health reforms supported by the
            project and the health aspects of the adjustment operations
            were supervised closely by the same health team ensuring
            that the policy dialogue with the authorities was consistent
            and linked to the overall macro level dialogue between the
            Government of Macedonia (GOM) and the Bank. Given the
            different players in the system, it was essential to aim at
            establishing early during project implementation a culture
            of better understanding the benefits of information for
            policy making. As noted earlier, team composition should
            have been strengthened earlier in the implementation process
            by the inclusion of a Health Information Management
            Specialist with international experience in health systems
            to guide the conceptualization and planning, and not only
            procurement processes.

12740541.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
12740541.trustfund:
TF026814-PHRD-FYR MACEDONIA: HEALTH
            SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Health Sector Management
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The specific objectives of the Health
            Sector Management Project for Macedonia are: (i) to upgrade
            Ministry of Health (MOH) and Health Insurance Fund (HIF)
            capacity to formulate and effectively implement health
            policies, health insurance, financial management, and
            contracting of providers; and (ii) to develop and implement
            an efficient scheme of restructuring of hospital services
            with emphasis on developing day-care services and shifting
            to primary care. The extension is necessary to complete
            procurement of information technology (IT) equipment.
            Bidding procedures are completed and contracts for IT
            equipment will be signed as soon as the extension of closing
            date is granted.  The activities that will be completed
            during the extension include delivery, acceptance and
            quality control of equipment.

display_title.display_title:
Macedonia - Health Sector
            Management Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

5129262.trustfund:
TF026814-PHRD-FYR MACEDONIA: HEALTH
            SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia -
            Health Sector Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Macedonia's
            higher level objectives are economic development, poverty
            reduction and the promotion of social stability and harmony.
            By addressing the important issue cost-containment while
            improving quality and access, the Health Sector Management
            Project will contribute to these higher-level objectives.
            The specific objectives of  this project are: (i) to upgrade
            the capacity of the Ministry of Health and the Health
            Insurance Fund to formulate and effectively implement health
            policies, health insurance, financial management and
            contracting of providers; and (ii) to develop and implement
            an efficient scheme of  restructuring of  hospital services
            with emphasis on developing day-care services and shifting
            to primary care. The project consists of four components.
            Component 1 supports policy formulation and implementation,
            specifically, Support to overall Health Policy and Strategy
            Development, public relations and communications, and
            improvement of the Ministry of Health's management and
            business process Component 2 strengthens governance and
            management of the Health Insurance Fund,, establishing
            eligibility criteria and a revenue collection system, and
            strengthening management processes, as well as improving the
            design and implementation of payment models and contracts,
            building staff capacity in areas relevant to purchasing,
            improving the management of drugs, and ensuring better
            tendering processes. Component 3 improves service delivery
            through supporting hospital management and improving primary
            care, and establishes a grant facility to improve service
            quality and efficiency. Component 4 supports project
            management and monitoring.

Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia -
            Health Sector Management Project
